Understate: The claim understates the fact that the FAQ document promising economic security to all Americans, even if they were unwilling to work, was indeed released by Ocasio-Cortez's office, although it was later acknowledged as incorrect by her adviser.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to prove that the FAQ document was doctored. It only mentions that an adviser to Ocasio-Cortez incorrectly stated that the document was doctored, without providing any evidence or further explanation.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the FAQ document was not put out by Ocasio-Cortez's office, without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the possibility of alternative explanations for the existence of the FAQ document, such as a mistake or miscommunication by Ocasio-Cortez's office.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the FAQ document was indeed released by Ocasio-Cortez's office, as acknowledged by her adviser.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing consistent and clear information about the origin and authenticity of the FAQ document. It mentions conflicting statements by Ocasio-Cortez's adviser and the existence of the document on her website, creating confusion.
Exaggerate: The claim does not appear to exaggerate any information or make exaggerated claims.
